comments.commentBody:
The air quality index is weighted by population density. So this is as much a sign of rapid urbanization and industrialization as anything else. Simply moving many industries away from populated areas (some of which is happening) would radically improve the ranking. It is arguable whether that means much for overall environmental health. But there are lies, damn lies, and rankings.

Interesting that Iraq is dead last in the overall rankings. I wonder why.

"D. Saha, a scientist in the “Air Lab” at India’s Central Pollution Control Board said the study’s findings were not a matter of huge concern."

Wow! I am left speechless -- if Saha is right, there is nothing to say. If he is wrong, then I am speechless in shock.

It is not surprising that india is leading in air pollution.So what should indians do? Everyone knows that the poor air quality is responsible for the increasing respiratory infections, cancer and even heart disease. So what should Indians do to reduce air pollution?
According to Dr.Gunasekhar , an air pollution expert:
Use public transport. Use L.P.G. (liquefied petroleum gas) in your home, rather than open fires. Plant more trees. Try carpooling.
What should individuals do to try to reduce pollution?

Because the USA has failed to provide air quality standards for women and children, air quality is ranked by its effect on a grown, healthy, heavy weight man. Poor environmental conditions that may sicken a man, can kill a young child, doom them to a life of sickness, placing the burden on government and humanitarian funds.

India's children are vital to the world's future. Children and adults sickened from poor air quality has been proven by the US Environmental Protection Agency to reduce their ability to function and learn.

Many products, services come from India as well as India providing the world with mathematicians, scientists, and doctors.

Our humanity is judged by how we take care of the least of us, the old, the young, and the sick.

Join and "Like" "Children's Environmental Protection Alliance" on Facebook and LinkedIn. Follow @ToxicJustice on Twitter.
www.toxicjustice.com
www.childrensepa.org

The reverse argument is being made these days to US educators. All this liberal artsy training isnt producing enough hard-nosed practical engineering professionals, for example.

It is really interesting to think of thhe Indian experience as the direction for American education's corrective course.

Meanwhile the Indian system seems to lack the creativity and humanism of the American.

I am from India and I absolutely cringe everytime I hear Republican candidates wanting to shut down EPA so that companies have easier time "to breathe".  You can't put price on clean air or clean water!

The most influential class in my life was a Theory of Knowledge course I took in high school. I started the course with a C- paper and spent the next two years honing my critical thinking and writing skills in that class. I cannot emphasize the importance of acquiring that skill set enough - the ability to ask the right questions, to pull apart an argument, write a critique, among other important skills.

An increasingly complex world like ours needs more well-rounded leaders than before. We need leaders who are equally comfortable spending time in quiet and deep contemplation on tough questions and sharing their insights eloquently with other people. That is not to say that an overly technical education can drive creativity and critical thinking out of a student's mind. However, an education without the opportunity to read Iago's lines from Othello or write an essay response to the question of whether knowledge is inherently good or evil is a poorer education.

You might be healthier if you included bitter foods in your diet.  Bitter, of course, is a relative term.  Foods can be both bitter and extremely delicious. Also, good black coffee is bitter, and is enjoyed by people the world over as a treat, right?

S.H.,

How dare you dissent from expert guidance regarding what is best for society? How dare you!

Life is only grim when individuals refuse to listen to expert guidance of the collective.

Physical pain is as nothing to the spirit pain that comes from ignoring the ravishments of consensus.

Comfort and relief are not for you.

Of course we crave sugar -- evolution took care of that one. And if we eat too much, it's not good. If you feel better going off sugar, do it. Give up alcohol, meat, animal products, prepared foods and any food that starts with the letter J. But leave the government out of it. Don't tell me what to eat and I won't tell you that people who lecture me about what I eat are tiresome at best. I live my life in the healthiest way I can. Sometimes, I eat sweets. I refuse to apologize for that, or to feel guilty. I'm a 55 year old woman who lives with a chronic disease (not even vaguely caused by my diet) and constant pain. Life can be grim sometimes. A delicious dessert, or a cup of tea with real sugar in it can be a comfort, or a relief. And sometimes, it's just a celebration of living in a world that includes the sweet with the bitter (which, by the way, I refuse to eat).

Why does it have to be one way or another, Autism or nothing at all? People on the mild end of the Autism/Asperger spectrum also of needs and benefit from understanding the background of their conditions, but they don't need the same label as autism. Why not have another definition for people who are on the spectrum and may have some issues, even if for the most they are not debilitating.

What is the worst way to start of black history month, than to hear a tragic story of the passing of a man who helped us love ourselves. There is nothing else to say, I'm heartbroken.

Thank you Mr. Cornelius for showing me how to have peace, love and SOUL! Rest in Paradise...

It was 1976 when my aunt and her friends used to watch the Soul~ Train. Nevermind they were Korean-Americans. Black music influenced so many not just in the U.S. but worldwide. And Don promulgated the effort. His legacy is expressed in virtually every so called K-Pop song today, whether the young Korean pop singers know it or not. But I remember. God bless Don. I hope you found peace.

February 1, 2012

Don Cornelius was one of the most significant individuals in the latter part of the 20th Century.

His contribution to American Popular Culture will remain in the annals of history of that time line.

KCS

Music Notes Magazine

How many of us have been to college parties when the odd shous of "upps, Soul Train" resulted in impromptu line dances breaking out?

Rest in Peace Mr. Cornelius and may the Lord give respite to your weary soul.
Always loved watchin, even the reruns now.  Woof.
Beautiful story... thank you for sharing.

Don Cornelius was a great host, I loved soul train, it taught white people how to dance or tried...lol God be with Mr. Cornelius. He was a genius and was his own man that never copied anyone’s style. He had his own style and it was cool. Don Cornelius was cool, he dressed cool he acted cool and he was cool. God be you Mr. Cornelius and thank you for the memories.

comments.commentTitle: Oh, for a DVD of the show!
comments.commentBody: Didn't get to see "The Boy From Oz" or this show, but I would hope that the Gods that Be....would arrange for this show to be recorded on a DVD.  I watched the very, very brief Video of his dancing that was presented with the Times Review and it was very entertaining.  Hope the producers of the show will take heed and produce a DVD for those who were not able to attend this remarkable performance.

I just happened to read that this was playing in New York when I was there a couple of weeks ago.  This bare-bones, no-frills production was outstanding.  The cast and the direction was flawless, bringing this play from the '60's and making it feel current and timeless.  It's a must see for serious theatre goers to experience a classic in such able hands.
Fine acting...and the choreographer of the physical aspects deserves an Obie!!  Kudos to a hardworking cast!

I will be going back for the third time to see the Living Theater's History of the World.  God bless Dame Malina and God bless the Living Theater, I'm sorry, forgot He was dead.  Well, Julian Beck bless LT cause they are still doing it and have never sold out on the belief that Theater is a powerful weapon for the War against the Machine and for the benefit of the people.  Each show I go to has the same impact on me that Paradise Now must have had on Jim Morrison.  And Beck bless also the wonderful acting activists who are the theatrical soldiers of the anarchistic revolution.  I am especially taken, as was my guest, Art Von Firstenberg, with the radiant presence of newcomer, abstract artist Kennedy Yanko.  And Beck bless Madam Molina.  I can't think of a more important theatrical artist activist that has done more for our country consciousness that MadaM (other than Katherine Dunham, of course).  Malina, who probably knows most of the History of the World personally brings all the youth, passion, vibrancy and chaos that most of us (not Arthur, of course) left behind in the 60s.  At only a tender 85, she is still  the youngest one on the set.  Before concluding, I would also like to mention a seldom appreciated art of the stage and that is lighting.  Brent Wellington, III is to be congratulated on encompassing each and every rapid historical set piece with the luminous ambiance and counterpoint that each deserves without calling attention to itself or muting the radiance of the passion of Malina's insight and commentary.  Finally, in the final act, all pretense and artifice is abandoned and laid bare,  leaving only the naked truth and Madam Malina on Her folding chair.  This show concludes this month, drop everything and bow down to godless goddess Malina while you still can.

Bill
Right wing propaganda that anyone the least bit informed knows is a lie. And, the reason there is so much debt - under Obama, as you claim, is because Bush did not even put the cost of the two wars he started on the books! Once that was put on the books, then it showed up for what it was- a huge waste of money, senseless deaths, and high war profits for his cronies like Halliburton. That mess was NOT ON THE BUDGET! Bush spent all that money - 40 cents on every dollar in the Iraq war going to Halliburton - and you want to blame Pres. Obama.
She cannot because she entered the country illegally.
well, at least carmen could get papers (status adjustment). her husband is an american citizen, and so is her baby. what's stopping her?

Read further into the reader comments and you will see that there are many legal Americans who would gladly have a job like this at $17 per hour.  I have Mexican friends, who are legal, who don't agree with employing illegals. It makes it more difficult on those who have followed the law and gotten their papers.
Hey, these are job creators you're talking about! They need that money!
It already is another Vietnam and has been for ten years.

The thundering NATO herd is in full retreat. It is what it is, and it's always been more about politics than real war fighting anyway. The Taliban are convinced they're winning (see the accompanying NYT article) and they may be right. It is deja vu-ey.  A liberal Democratic administration, insisting that because everything in the faraway foreign war is going swimmingly we'll be packing up soon and leaving, thank you so very much, is slowly revealed to be clumsy realpolitik smoke blowers. Given that this administration is supposed to be the best and the brightest, it's a little awkward. As for all those rejoicing at the imminent end of "Bush's Wars", we can all only hope that this heavily publicized withdrawal announcement in this election year is not a prelude to another...well, we all know what. Please, not that.
